TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit WebPartCollection extends System.Collections.ReadOnlyCollectionBase

Docs.summary: Contains a collection of controls used to track and manage related groups of controls. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The WebPartCollection class is a read-only collection of controls, typically used by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> controls to manage sets of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls.
A <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control uses a WebPartCollection object to keep a list of all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on a page, whereas a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> control uses a WebPartCollection object to track the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls that it contains.
> [!NOTE] > The WebPartCollection collection contains both <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls and other server controls (such as user controls, custom controls, and ASP.NET controls) that are placed in <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> zones and used as part of Web Parts applications. So, for example, if you have a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZone> zone in a page, and within it you declare a custom <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control and the ASP.NET <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Calendar> control, both controls will be in the WebPartCollection collection referenced by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A> property.
The WebPartCollection object exists so that the Web Parts control set can work with strongly typed collections. Similarly, if you want to perform mass operations on a set of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls, you can get a reference to a WebPartCollection object using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A> property. For example, you might want to loop through all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on a page and change their appearance in some way. Even though the WebPartCollection object is read-only, you can make programmatic changes to the properties of the underlying controls referenced in the collection.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of the WebPartCollection object on a Web Parts page. This example has three parts:
- The code for the page in a partial class.
- The Web page that contains the controls.
- A description of how the example works in a browser.
The first part of the code example contains the code for the page in a partial class. Note that the `Button1_Click` method creates a WebPartCollection object that consists of all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls referenced in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property, which includes all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on the page. The method iterates through all the controls, and toggles each control's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.ChromeState%2A> property, which determines whether that control is normal or minimized.
[!code-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.web.ui.webcontr_100_1.vb)] [!code-cs[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.web.ui.webcontr_100_1.cs)]
The second part of the code example is the Web page that contains the controls. Notice that the controls declared in `WebPartZone1` are standard ASP.NET server controls, but because they are wrapped as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> controls at run time, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> class inherits from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> class, the controls are automatically treated as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls at run time and therefore are included in the WebPartCollection object.
[!code-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.web.ui.webcontr_100_2.aspx)] [!code-cs[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.web.ui.webcontr_100_2.aspx)]
After you load the page in a browser and click the **Toggle ChromeState** button, the code in the partial class loops through the WebPartCollection object and alternately minimizes the controls or returns them to normal. Or, if you repeatedly click the **Toggle BulletedList1 Title** button, the title of the uppermost control is changed to alternate values.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes an empty new instance of the class.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The WebPartCollection constructor initializes an empty instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> class. The object itself is read-only and has no method to add individual <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls to it; therefore, you will have little occasion to use this constructor.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class System.Collections.ICollection webParts) cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of a object by passing in an <xref:System.Collections.ICollection> collection of controls.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The WebPartCollection constructor initializes an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> class by passing in a collection of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls.
Although a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object is read-only and there is no method for adding individual controls to it, you can create your own <xref:System.Collections.ICollection> collection of controls, and pass that to the WebPartCollection constructor. This enables you to create custom collections and perform bulk operations on them. You can also access the underlying controls in the collection and change their property values programmatically.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of the WebPartCollection constructor on a Web Parts page. This example has three parts:
- The code for the page in a partial class.
- The Web page that contains the controls.
- A description of how the example works in a browser.
The first part of the code example contains the code for the page in a partial class. Note that the `Button1_Click` method creates a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object that consists of all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls referenced in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.WebParts%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property, which includes all the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on the page. The method iterates through all the controls, and toggles each control's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.ChromeState%2A> property, which determines whether that control is normal or minimized.
[!code-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/925c1270-ace5-4ee4-8afb-_1.vb)] [!code-cs[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/925c1270-ace5-4ee4-8afb-_1.cs)]
The second part of the code example is the Web page that contains the controls. Notice that the controls declared in `WebPartZone1` are standard ASP.NET server controls, but because they are wrapped as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> controls at run time, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> class inherits from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> class, the controls are automatically treated as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls at run time and therefore are included in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object.
[!code-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/925c1270-ace5-4ee4-8afb-_2.aspx)] [!code-cs[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/925c1270-ace5-4ee4-8afb-_2.aspx)]
After you load the page in a browser, click the **Toggle ChromeState** button, and notice that the code in the partial class loops through the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object and alternately minimizes the controls or returns them to normal. Or, if you repeatedly click the **Toggle BulletedList1 Title** button, the title of the uppermost control is changed to alternate values.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance bool Contains(class System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart value) cil managed

Docs.param: A that is checked to determine whether it is in the collection.
Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether a particular control exists in the collection.
Docs.returns: A Boolean value that indicates whether a particular control is in the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The Contains method enables you to check a particular <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> object and determine whether it is part of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object.

MemberSignature.Value: public void CopyTo (System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart[] array, int index);
.method public hidebysig instance void CopyTo(class System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart[] array, int32 index) cil managed

Docs.param: An array of objects to contain the copied collection.
The starting point in the array at which to place the collection contents.
Docs.summary: Copies the collection to an array of objects.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The CopyTo method is useful when you want to assemble a custom array that can contain the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object, a subset of those controls, or a superset of those controls.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance int32 IndexOf(class System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart value) cil managed

Docs.param: A that is a member of the collection.
Docs.summary: Returns the position of a particular member of the collection.
Docs.returns: An integer that indicates the position of a particular object in the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The IndexOf method is useful if you have multiple <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls on a Web Parts page, and you need to know the ordinal position of one control relative to the others.

Docs.param: The index of a particular control in a collection.
Docs.summary: Returns a member of the collection based on its position in the collection.
Docs.value: A at the specified index in the collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The Item indexer allows you to access the underlying <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object by index, and change their property values or call methods.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of the Item indexer on a Web Parts page. This example has three parts:
- The code for the page in a partial class.
- The Web page that contains the controls.
- A description of how the example works in a browser.
The first part of the code example contains the code for the page in a partial class. Note that the `Button2_Click` method creates an empty <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object, then assigns to it the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls from the `WebPartZone1.WebParts` property. The method accesses the first control in the collection by using its index, and toggles its <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.Title%2A> property value.
[!code-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_990_1.vb)] [!code-cs[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_990_1.cs)]
The second part of the code example is the Web page that contains the controls. Notice that the controls declared in `WebPartZone1` are standard ASP.NET server controls, but because they are wrapped as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> controls at run time, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> class inherits from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> class, the controls can be treated as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls at run time and made part of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object.
[!code-vb[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_990_2.aspx)] [!code-cs[WebParts_WebPartCollection_Overview#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.web.ui.webcontr_990_2.aspx)]
After you load the page in a browser, click the **Toggle BulletedList1 Title** button, and notice that the code toggles the title of the control between the two available title choices.

Docs.param: The unique identifier for a particular control in a collection.
Docs.summary: Returns a member of the collection based on a unique string identifier.
Docs.value: The first in the collection whose ID equals the value of .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The Item indexer enables you to access a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object according to a unique identifier.
> [!NOTE] > The Web Parts control set performs case-insensitive matching on this property, so case sensitivity is not part of a unique `id` value.
The Item property also works to identify members of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartCollection> object in some specialized cases. In the case of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> controls, the indexer is able to match the identifier for the underlying child control wrapped by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> control. In the case of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart> controls, the indexer matches the identifier for the control based on a case-insensitive comparison of the `id` parameter and either the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart.OriginalID%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart.GenericWebPartID%2A> property values.
